ai-dn25:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
ai-dn25:1.3_0: Now at that time the wanderer Nigrodha was residing at Udumbarikā’s monastery for wanderers.
ai-dn25:1.4_0: Then, householder, the householder Sandhāna went back to see the Buddha.

ai-dn25:1.8_0: And it’s not appropriate for the esteemed mendicants,
ai-dn25:1.10_0: Why don’t I visit the wanderer Nigrodha at the lady Udumbarikā’s monastery for wanderers?”
ai-dn25:1.11_0: So he went to the monastery of the wanderers.
ai-dn25:2.1_0: Now at that time, Nigrodha was sitting together with a large assembly of wanderers making an uproar, a dreadful racket. They engaged in all kinds of unworthy talk, such as
ai-dn25:2.2_0: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
ai-dn25:3.1_0: Nigrodha saw Sandhāna coming off in the distance,
ai-dn25:3.3_0: “Be quiet, good sirs, don’t make a sound.
ai-dn25:3.4_0: The householder Sandhāna, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama, is coming.
ai-dn25:3.5_0: He is included among the white-clothed lay disciples of the ascetic Gotama, who is residing near Rājagaha.
ai-dn25:3.6_0: Such venerables like the quiet, are educated to be quiet, and praise the quiet.
ai-dn25:3.7_0: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
ai-dn25:3.8_0: After this was said, those wanderers fell silent.
ai-dn25:4.1_0: Then Sandhāna went up to the wanderer Nigrodha, and exchanged greetings with him.
ai-dn25:4.2_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-dn25:4.3_0: “The way the wanderers make an uproar as they sit together and talk about all kinds of unworthy topics is one thing.
ai-dn25:4.4_0: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
ai-dn25:4.5_0: It’s quite different to the way the Buddha frequents remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat.”
ai-dn25:5.1_0: When Sandhāna said this, Nigrodha said to him,
ai-dn25:5.2_0: “Surely, householder, you should know better! With whom does the ascetic Gotama converse? With whom does he engage in discussion? With whom does he achieve lucidity of wisdom?
ai-dn25:5.3_0: Staying in empty huts has destroyed the ascetic Gotama’s wisdom. Not frequenting assemblies, he is unable to hold a discussion.
ai-dn25:5.4_0: He just lurks on the periphery.
ai-dn25:5.5_0: He’s just like the nilgai antelope, circling around and lurking on the periphery.

ai-dn25:5.9_0: He just lurks on the periphery.
ai-dn25:5.10_0: Please, householder, let the ascetic Gotama come to this assembly. I’ll sink him with just one question! I’ll roll him over and wrap him up like a hollow pot!”
ai-dn25:6.1_0: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha heard this discussion between the householder Sandhāna and the wanderer Nigrodha.
ai-dn25:6.2_0: Then the Buddha descended Vulture’s Peak Mountain and went to the peacocks’ feeding ground on the bank of the Sumāgadhā.
ai-dn25:6.2_1: and after going, while walking, in the open air, he was walking mindfully in the open air.

ai-dn25:6.8_0: If the ascetic Gotama comes, I’ll ask him this question:

ai-dn25:7.15_0: “It’s hard for you to understand this, Nigrodha, since you have a different view, creed, preference, practice, and tradition.

ai-dn25:7.17_0: ‘How are the conditions for the mortification in disgust of sin completed, and how are they incomplete?’”

ai-dn25:8.1_0: Then Nigrodha, having quieted those wanderers, said to the Buddha,

ai-dn25:8.4_0: “It’s when a mortifier goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when asked. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on purpose for them, or an invitation for a meal.
ai-dn25:8.5_0: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who has a man in her home; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. ai-dn25:8.6_0: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls. They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
ai-dn25:8.7_0: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
ai-dn25:8.8_0: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen.

ai-dn25:8.19_0: They eat unnatural things, committed to the practice of eating unnatural foods.

ai-dn25:8.23_0: If this is so, is the mortification in disgust of sin completed, or not?”

ai-dn25:16.0_0: Discussion of the proper conduct for purity
ai-dn25:16.1_0: “But at what point, sir, does the mortification in disgust of sin reach the peak and the pith?

ai-dn25:16.4_0: And how is a mortifier restrained in the fourfold restraint?

ai-dn25:16.15_0: Giving up ill will, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will and malevolence.
ai-dn25:16.16_0: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.

ai-dn25:19.11_0: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding.
ai-dn25:19.11_2: They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
ai-dn25:19.12_0: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds:
ai-dn25:19.12_1: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-dn25:19.12_2: They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view.
ai-dn25:19.12_3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ai-dn25:19.12_4: at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a good destination, a heaven world.’
ai-dn25:19.12_5: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
ai-dn25:19.14_0: If this is so, is the mortification in disgust of sin purified or not?”
ai-dn25:19.15_0: “Clearly, sir, it is purified. It has reached the peak and the pith.”
ai-dn25:19.16_0: “Nigrodha, at this point the mortification in disgust of sin has reached the peak and the pith.
ai-dn25:19.17_0: Nigrodha, remember you said this to me:
ai-dn25:19.18_0: ‘Sir, what teaching do you use to guide your disciples, through which they claim solace in the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life?’
ai-dn25:19.19_0: Well, there is something better and finer than this. That’s what I use to guide my disciples, through which they claim solace in the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life.”
ai-dn25:19.20_0: When he said this, those wanderers made an uproar,
ai-dn25:19.21_0: “In that case, we’re lost, and so is our tradition! We don’t know anything better or finer than that!”
ai-dn25:20.2_0: “Obviously, now these wanderers want to listen to what the Buddha says. They’re paying attention and applying their minds to understand!”
ai-dn25:20.3_0: So he said to the wanderer Nigrodha,
ai-dn25:20.4_0: “Nigrodha, remember you said this to me:
ai-dn25:20.5_0: ‘Surely, householder, you should know better! With whom does the ascetic Gotama converse? With whom does he engage in discussion? With whom does he achieve lucidity of wisdom?
ai-dn25:20.6_0: Staying in empty huts has destroyed the ascetic Gotama’s wisdom. Not frequenting assemblies, he is unable to hold a discussion. He just lurks on the periphery.
ai-dn25:20.7_0: He’s just like the nilgai antelope, circling around and lurking on the periphery.
ai-dn25:20.8_0: In the same way, the ascetic Gotama has destroyed the wisdom of empty huts. Not frequenting assemblies, he is unable to hold a discussion.
ai-dn25:20.8_1: He just lurks on the periphery.
ai-dn25:20.9_0: Please, householder, let the ascetic Gotama come to this assembly. I’ll sink him with just one question! I’ll roll him over and wrap him up like a hollow pot!’
ai-dn25:20.10_0: Now the Blessed One, perfected and fully awakened, has arrived here. Why don’t you send him out of the assembly to the periphery like a nilgai antelope? Why don’t you sink him with just one question? Why don’t you roll him over and wrap him up like a hollow pot?”
ai-dn25:20.11_0: When he said this, Nigrodha sat silent, embarrassed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
ai-dn25:21.1_0: Knowing this, the Buddha said to the wanderers:
ai-dn25:21.2_0: “Is it really true, Nigrodha—are those your words?”
ai-dn25:21.3_0: “It’s true, sir, those are my words. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me.”
ai-dn25:21.5_0: Have you heard that wanderers of the past who were elderly and senior, the teachers of teachers, said that
ai-dn25:21.6_0: when the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas of the past came together, they made an uproar,
ai-dn25:21.7_0: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
ai-dn25:21.8_0: like you do in your tradition these days?
ai-dn25:21.9_0: Or did they say that the Buddhas frequented remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat, like I do these days?”
ai-dn25:21.10_0: “I have heard that wanderers of the past who were elderly and senior, said that
ai-dn25:21.11_0: when the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas of the past came together, they didn’t make an uproar,
ai-dn25:21.12_0: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
ai-dn25:21.13_0: like I do in my tradition these days.
ai-dn25:21.14_0: “Did the Buddhas frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat, like the Buddha?”
ai-dn25:21.15_0: “It occurs to you, Nigrodha, that is not enough for you,
ai-dn25:21.16_0: ‘The Blessed One is awakened, tamed, serene, crossed over, and extinguished. And he teaches Dhamma for awakening, taming, serenity, crossing over, and extinguishment’?”
ai-dn25:22.0_0: for the culmination of the spiritual path
ai-dn25:22.2_0: “I have made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me to speak in that way.
ai-dn25:22.3_0: Please accept my confession for my future restraint.”
ai-dn25:22.4_0: “Indeed, Nigrodha, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to speak in that way.
ai-dn25:22.5_0: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.
ai-dn25:22.6_0: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.
ai-dn25:22.7_0: Nigrodha, this is what I say:
ai-dn25:22.8_0: ‘Come on, let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.
ai-dn25:22.9_0: By practicing as instructed they will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life, in seven years. They will live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-dn25:22.11_0: Let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.
ai-dn25:22.12_0: By practicing as instructed they will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life, in six years ...
ai-dn25:22.19_0: Let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.
ai-dn25:22.30_0: Let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.
ai-dn25:22.31_0: By practicing as instructed they will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life, in seven days.
ai-dn25:23.3_0: But you should not see it like this.
ai-dn25:23.4_0: Let your teacher remain your teacher.
ai-dn25:23.6_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to give up our park.’
ai-dn25:23.7_0: But you should not see it like this.
ai-dn25:23.8_0: Let your recitation remain as it is.
ai-dn25:23.10_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to give up our livelihood.’
ai-dn25:23.11_0: But you should not see it like this.
ai-dn25:23.12_0: Let your livelihood remain as it is.
ai-dn25:23.14_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to start doing things that are unskillful and considered unskillful in our tradition.’
ai-dn25:23.15_0: But you should not see it like this.
ai-dn25:23.16_0: Let those things that are unskillful and considered unskillful in your tradition remain as they are.
ai-dn25:23.18_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to stop doing things that are skillful and considered skillful in our tradition.’
ai-dn25:23.19_0: But you should not see it like this.
ai-dn25:23.20_0: Let those things that are skillful and considered skillful in your tradition remain as they are.
ai-dn25:23.21_0: I do not speak for any of these reasons.
ai-dn25:23.22_0: Nigrodha, there are things that are unskillful, corrupted, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. I teach Dhamma so that those things may be given up.
ai-dn25:23.23_0: When you practice accordingly, corrupting qualities will be given up in you and cleansing qualities will grow. You’ll enter and remain in the fullness and abundance of wisdom, having realized it with your own insight in this very life.”
ai-dn25:24.1_0: When this was said, those wanderers sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say, as if their minds were possessed by Māra.
ai-dn25:24.3_0: “All these foolish people have been touched by the Wicked One!
ai-dn25:24.4_0: For not even a single one thinks,
ai-dn25:24.5_0: ‘Well, let’s go of the ascetic Gotama to lead the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama. What will we do for seven days?’”
ai-dn25:24.6_0: Then the Buddha, having roared his lion’s roar in the lady Udumbarikā’s monastery for wanderers, rose into the air and landed on Vulture’s Peak.
ai-dn25:24.7_0: Meanwhile, the householder Sandhāna just went back to Rājagaha.
ai-dn25:24.8_0: The second chapter on offenses is finished.
